Award.AwardTitle: Canonical metrics on four dimensional manifolds, and orbifold structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1309029, Principal Investigator: Ioana Suvaina

The main goal of the proposed research is the study of Riemannian geometry of orbifold spaces in dimension four, and how they appear as boundary points of the space of canonical metrics on smooth manifolds. The principal investigator proposes to analyze a family of problems addressing the study of the space of constant scalar curvature Kaehler surfaces. The projects proposed concern both problems on the local development of singularities, but also the understanding of compact smooth spaces. The principal investigator aims to establish connections between the algebraic geometry aspects of the problems and their counterparts in Kaehler geometry. The resolution of these projects will provide constructions of new examples of constant scalar curvature Kaehler surfaces, or constant scalar curvature almost Kaehler 4-manifolds. In another direction, the principal investigator proposes a series of projects on the relations between estimates of the curvature components, the topological and differential invariants of a 4-orbifold, and existence or non-existence of Einstein metrics. The main approach is via the Seiberg-Witten theory.

The study of the four dimensional spaces has a long history both in mathematics and physics being motivated by the study of the space-time model. In mathematics, there is strong evidence that the four dimensional spaces are very special as they admit infinitely many smooth structures. This research program plans to use techniques from different fields in mathematics: differential topology, Riemannian and Kaehler geometry, and algebraic geometry to study four dimensional spaces. In particular, the principal investigator aims to establish new connections among these various fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this award has consisted of several phases and inter-related projects. The PI's projects have originated from the study of four dimensional spaces endowed with special metrics, which occur in different generalizations of the space-time. One long term project focuses on studying the smooth structures on 4-spaces, and in particular existence and relations between canonical and exotic smooth structures. In this direction she has exhibited a large family of symmetries on simply connected four-manifolds, and computed a numerical invariant on a class of symplectic manifolds, thus given new insights in the geometry of symplectic 4-manifolds. On a second long term project the PI studies the ALE Kahler manifolds. On a first phase she classified the ALE Kahler surfaces with trivial Ricci curvature, thus generalizing the Kronheimer's classification of gravitational instantons. She then pursued a second phase where she established bridges connecting the study of the ALE Ricci flat Kahler manifolds from the perspective of twistor geometry or complex analysis. Recently, the PI was able to give a characterization of the underlying complex space of a ALE Kahler manifold in arbitrary dimension. The PI expects that this project will have a tremendous development in the near future, and will impact several areas in the study of complex geometry. Lastly, the PI has studied problems on higher dimensional complex manifolds which are endowed with Hermitian metrics. This is an emerging area, generalizing Kahler geometry, which requires new techniques and much of the intuition in its study is still a work in progress.

During the period of the award the PI has published four papers, one paper was accepted for publication and  finished two other papers, which are available to the mathematical community on the ArXiv server.

 

The PI has also spent considerable time on mathematical education and outreach. She mentored one postdoctoral associate and more than a dozen undergraduate students majoring in mathematics. She developed the curriculum at Vanderbilt University by introducing a new advanced undergraduate course in differential geometry. During the period of the award the PI organized three two days workshops, a week long conference and a AMS special session on the general area of differential geometry. She is also one of the main organizers of a weekly seminar in Geometry and Topology at Vanderbilt University. She promulgated her research by given talks in numerous international conferences and seminars. The PI believes that involving and attracting people to STEM education should start at an early period of their development, hence she gave lectures in the Vanderbilt Math. Circle, a faculty organized two hours weekly advanced problem session for highly motivated high-school or middle school students from Nashville area.

During her all activities, the PI made a special effort to encourage, promote and mentor the participation in the mathematical community of members of under-represented minorities, especially female mathematicians. In particular, she has co-funded the Vanderbilt Women in Mathematics group to be involved in the professional development of junior female mathematicians at her university.
